channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand Dies at 88; Reigned 70 Years
item.media:description: Mourners after an announcement that King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand had died, outside the Siriraj hospital in Bangkok on Thursday.
item.description: The king, one of history’s longest-reigning monarchs, was a unifying figure in a deeply polarized country.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA CROSSETTE

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Scorned Abroad, Remains Popular in the Philippines
item.media:description: Virgilio Mabag, 54, standing in front of a poster of President Rodrigo Duterte in Pasay, the Philippines. “This is the only time I’ve seen a president like this, who says exactly what he wants to say,” he said.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: About 1,400 people have been killed by the police in President Duterte’s antidrug operations, but he has also pushed ahead with progressive and popular social policies.
item.dc:creator: AURORA ALMENDRAL

item.title: Afghan Forces, Their Numbers Dwindling Sharply, Face a Resurgent Taliban
item.media:description: The Afghan Special Forces, who bear the brunt of the fighting, are overused and exhausted, increasingly deployed for long periods.
item.description: A massacre of at least 100 police officers and soldiers on Tuesday, among the worst in a forgotten war, hits forces already demoralized and struggling to fill their ranks.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: ‘True Scale’ of India’s Tuberculosis Problem: 2.8 Million New Cases
item.media:description: A tuberculosis patient at a hospital in Bhopal, India, in March. The World Health Organization’s estimate of new global TB patients has risen to 10.4 million.
item.description: Finally coming to terms with the enormity of its TB problem, India is preparing a radical overhaul and expansion of its national treatment program.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Secrets of the Kingdom: Saudi Arabia, Where Even Milk Depends on Oil, Struggles to Remake Its Economy
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Low crude prices and the war in Yemen have sent a shock through the kingdom’s budget and forced it to revise its social contract even as it seeks to diversify its businesses.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: U.S. Ship Off Yemen Fires Missiles at Houthi Rebel Sites
item.description: The strikes are the first time the United States has directly attacked Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who are fighting the Yemeni government.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MARK MAZZETTI
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Kerry Opens a New Diplomatic Push for a Cease-Fire in Aleppo
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated after an airstrike in the rebel-held neighborhood of Douma in the Syrian capital on Wednesday.
item.description: The secretary of state will meet with representatives from the regional powers most directly involved in the Syria conflict.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: U.N. Picks Powerful Feminist (Wonder Woman) for Visible Job (Mascot)
item.media:description: The United Nations is set to make Wonder Woman an honorary ambassador.
item.description: The United Nations, which recently rejected seven female candidates vying to lead it, said it would appoint Wonder Woman as an honorary ambassador.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: António Guterres, New U.N. Leader, Inherits Tough Challenges
item.description: Mr. Guterres will take over as secretary general of the United Nations at a time when the credibility of the world body is under intense scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Memo From Britain: Facing ‘Brexit,’ Lawmakers Ask How to ‘Make Britain Great Again’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain gave a speech about Britain’s decision to leave the European Union at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, England, last week.
item.description: Conservatives in Parliament want all the old symbols of the island nation’s empire — including a royal yacht — as they continue to call for a ‘hard Brexit.’
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Terrorism Suspect’s Suicide Adds to Scrutiny of German Security Services
item.media:description: Jaber al-Bakr, a Syrian refugee.
item.media:credit: Christian Zander/Saxony Police, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The death is almost certain to add to pressure on the state and federal authorities to improve coordination among the patchwork of agencies responsible for law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Scottish Govt Takes Step Toward Another Independence Vote
item.description: Next week the Scottish government will publish a bill laying the groundwork for a new independence referendum, the country's leader announced Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Boko Haram Releases 21 Girls Kidnapped From School in Chibok, Nigeria Says
item.media:description: A still from a video released in August showing a man described as a Boko Haram fighter with some of the girls abducted from a school in Chibok, Nigeria, in 2014.
item.description: Officials revealed last month that they had been negotiating with the Islamist militant group to gain the release of girls taken in April 2014.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Militia Fighters Kill 13 in Central African Republic
item.description: Displaced people living in the northern town of Kaga-Bandoro were attacked by militia fighters before United Nations peacekeepers repelled them.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Dutch Law Would Allow Euthanasia for Healthy Elderly People
item.description: Proponents say there are valid reasons besides terminal illness to choose to die, among them loss of independence, deterioration and loneliness.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Maldives to Leave Commonwealth Over Allegations of Rights Abuses
item.description: The government said it had been treated “unjustly and unfairly” over questions about its human rights record.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘The Greatest Loss and Despair’: Thais Mourn Their King
item.media:description: Well-wishers outside the Siriraj Hospital moments after the announcement of King Bhumibol Aulyadej’s death in Bangkok on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: King Bhumibol Adulyadej was the only monarch most Thais had ever known, and his death Thursday set off an outpouring of grief across the nation.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: What the Death of Thailand’s King Means, and What’s Next
item.media:description: King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand in 2008.
item.description: The transition of power could become a turning point for a country long divided by rival political factions.
item.dc:creator: DANIELLE BELOPOTOSKY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Kiss the Boss’ Video Highlights Risks of a ‘Post-Truth’ China
item.description: Footage of a boss who reportedly required his female staff members to kiss him each morning to “boost morale” was fake, said employees of a company at the center of the commotion.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere: Xi Jinping Reminds China’s State Companies of Who’s the Boss
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing. This week he indicated that he was unwilling to relinquish too much control over China’s state enterprises.
item.description: In an unusual meeting, the Chinese president said the Communist Party must take a greater role in the boardroom — despite earlier pledges toward reform.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Methamphetamine Abuse Colors Politics in the Philippines
item.media:description: Sachets of shabu, a cheap form of methamphetamine, and paraphernalia placed in front of arrested drug suspects in Manila, the Philippine capital, last month.
item.description: President Rodrigo Duterte’s bloody antidrug campaign has taken particular aim at shabu, a cheap form of methamphetamine that has caused grave health and social problems.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Dario Fo, Whose Plays Won Praise, Scorn and a Nobel, Dies at 90
item.media:description: Dario Fo, who won the 1997 Nobel Prize in Literature, in Rome in December.
item.description: He was best known for the “Accidental Death of an Anarchist” and his one-man show “Mistero Buffo” (“Comic Mystery”), and he was awarded the 1997 Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN KANDELL

item.title: Australian Police Say 2 Teenagers Planned ‘Imminent Attack’
item.media:description: Michael Phelan, deputy commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, and Catherine Burn, deputy police commissioner of New South Wales, at a news conference in Sydney on Thursday.
item.description: The police said that two 16-year-old boys arrested with knives in a Sydney suburb were inspired by the Islamic State but that they did not know of a specific target.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Venezuela’s Supreme Court Consolidates President Nicolás Maduro’s Power
item.media:description: Venezuela’s Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that President Nicolás Maduro could pass his 2017 budget without approval of the country’s opposition-majority legislature.
item.media:credit: Venezuelan Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: In a ruling late Tuesday, the court removed budgetary authority from the nation’s Congress, the only institution that is controlled by the opposition.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Syrian Refugee in German Terror Case Kills Himself in Jail
item.media:description: Jaber al-Bakr, in an image released by the police.
item.description: Jaber al-Bakr, 22, took his own life in a jail cell in Leipzig, where he had been taken after being arrested on suspicion of planning an imminent attack.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Raising Fears of a Flight from International Criminal Court, Burundi Heads for Exit
item.media:description: The lower house of Burundi’s Parliament voted on Wednesday to withdraw the country from the International Criminal Court.
item.description: The country’s lower house of Parliament has voted overwhelmingly to withdraw from the International Criminal Court, something that other nations have threatened to do.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Migrant Children, Alone and Desperate in Calais, Look to Britain With Hope
item.media:description: Tents at “the Jungle” migrant camp outside Calais, France.
item.description: With the French government’s planned dismantling of the migrant camp looming, officials say Britain may finally be accelerating steps to admit dozens of children.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Violence Mounts in Restive Myanmar State, Leaving a Dozen Dead
item.media:description: A soldier patrolling at the entrance of Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, on Monday. Reports indicated a significant escalation of tension in the state, which has long been a site of sectarian conflict.
item.description: A rights group reported the extrajudicial killings of Muslims in Rakhine by the army, days after nine police officers in the border area were killed.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Donald Trump Is ‘Dangerous’ for Global Stability, U.N. Rights Chief Says
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the high commissioner for human rights, doubled down on remarks he gave last month condemning “nationalist demagogues.”
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Gagra Journal: Bad Pipes, Worse Service: A Soviet Riviera Jewel Is Reborn and Booking Up
item.media:description: A promenade outside the 240-room Amra International in Gagra, Georgia. After a long slump, the colonnaded property is enjoying something of a renaissance.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: After a long slump that began with the collapse of the Soviet Union, a once exclusive sanitarium along Georgia’s Black Sea coast is enjoying something of a renaissance.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Worries Over King Bhumibol Adulyadej’s Health Shake Thailand
item.description: The country’s prime minister returned abruptly to Bangkok and well-wishers waited at the hospital where the 88-year-old monarch was being treated.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Lawyers for Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Resign
item.description: Mr. Abdeslam, the sole surviving assailant from the Nov. 13 terrorist assaults, has remained silent and has indicated that he no longer wants representation.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Sinosphere: At Hong Kong Swearing-In, Some Lawmakers Pepper Their Oath With Jabs
item.media:description: Leung Kwok-hung ripped up a copy of the Chinese government’s restrictive ruling on Hong Kong election procedures after taking the oath of office in the Legislative Council on Wednesday. The yellow umbrella is a symbol of the 2014 pro-democracy protests.
item.description: The acts of defiance, directed at Beijing as some called for outright independence for the semiautonomous territory, seemed to augur a stormy legislative term.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong

item.title: Emerging Climate Accord Could Push A/C Out of Sweltering India’s Reach
item.media:description: Air-conditioning units in New Delhi.
item.description: A phaseout of hydrofluorocarbons could have a major effect on climate change but would make air-conditioning more expensive just as many Indians are becoming able to afford it.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: What in the World: Who’s That Voice Asking for Scrap Metal in Mexico? A 10-Year-Old Girl
item.description: A collector of recyclable goods got tired of shouting through a megaphone, so he asked his daughter to record a message for him. It’s now used by hundreds of merchants.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: What in the World: When You Have to Go, Japanese Rest Stops Won’t Keep You Waiting
item.media:description: Monitors at the rest stop let visitors see immediately which stalls inside the restroom are empty.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Amenities like five times as many stalls for women, and monitors showing the vacant ones, aim to make sure traffic is the only delay to worry about.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Opinion: Why Chinese Women Still Can’t Get a Break
item.description: Social changes that have given urban Chinese women new liberties and ambitions often impede their freedom in other ways.
item.dc:creator: HELEN GAO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bollywood Goes to War
item.description: Pakistani terrorists hit India. India’s army hits back — and its film industry, too.
item.dc:creator: SONIA FALEIRO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Perpetual Panic of American Parenthood
item.media:description: Children attend a classroom at a preschool in Paris in 2015.
item.description: Make our country great, by making it a bit more like the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: PAMELA DRUCKERMAN

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
